title: RS22784
content: Section 1512 of the law pertains to obstructing federal proceedings, including congressional, judicial, or executive processes. It encompasses four main crimes: using force or threats to prevent evidence production, using deception or intimidation for the same purpose, destroying or hiding evidence, and harassing witnesses to impede evidence production. The penalties vary based on the type of obstructive behavior, such as violence leading to a witness not testifying or producing evidence. Subsection 1512(k) makes conspiracy to violate Section 1512 a separate offense subject to the same penalties as the underlying offense. Conspirators are criminally liable under the Pinkerton doctrine for any crime committed in the foreseeable furtherance of the conspiracy. Accomplices to a violation of subsection 1512(a) may incur criminal liability by operation of 18 U.S.C. 2, 3, 4, or 373 as well. Accomplices to a violation of subsection 1512(a) may face criminal liability under 18 U.S.C. 2, 3, 4, or 373. Section 2 treats accomplices before the fact as principals, while Section 3 outlaws acting as an accessory after the fact. To aid and abet a crime, the defendant must associate with the venture and seek to make it succeed. It is also necessary to prove that someone else committed the underlying offense. Prosecution for misprision of felony under 18 U.S.C. 4 requires knowledge of a felony, failure to notify authorities, and steps to conceal the crime. The offense carries a maximum penalty of three years imprisonment and/or a fine of $250,000. Solicitation to commit a crime of violence under 18 U.S.C. 373 requires intent for another to commit the offense. Section 373 of the law requires the government to prove that the defendant intended for someone else to commit a violent crime and took actions to persuade them to do so. There is a defense if the offender prevents the crime from happening. Penalties are half of the sanctions for the original offense, with a maximum of 20 years in prison for crimes punishable by death or life imprisonment. Violating subsection 1512(a) can lead to prosecution for other crimes, such as money laundering and racketeering under RICO statutes. The RICO statutes outlaw acquiring or conducting the affairs of an interstate enterprise through a pattern of predicate offenses, punishable by imprisonment for up to 20 years, a fine of up to $250,000, and confiscation of related property. Money laundering provisions prohibit financial transactions involving proceeds of a predicate offense, punishable by imprisonment for up to 20 years, a fine, and confiscation of related property. Section 1512 offenses include obstruction of federal activities by intimidation, threat, corrupt persuasion, or deception. Section 1512 of the law prohibits various forms of obstruction of official proceedings, including intimidation, threats, corrupt persuasion, and deception. It also covers destruction of evidence and harassment of federal witnesses. Offenses under this section can result in imprisonment for up to 20 years. Section 1513 prohibits witness or informant retaliation, including bodily harm, property damage, and economic retaliation against federal witnesses in court proceedings. Offenses under this section are RICO and money laundering predicate offenses, with penalties similar to Section 1503. Section 1505 outlaws obstructing congressional or federal administrative proceedings, punishable by up to five years in prison. Section 1505 prohibits obstructing federal administrative or congressional proceedings, with penalties of up to five years imprisonment (up to eight years for terrorism-related offenses). The crime requires awareness of the pending proceeding and intentional corrupt endeavors to influence or impede it. It is not considered a RICO or money laundering predicate offense. Conspiracy to obstruct such proceedings can be prosecuted under 18 U.S.C. 371, with aiding and abetting laws also applicable. The elements of conspiracy to defraud the United States include an agreement between individuals to defraud the government, with an overt act in furtherance of the scheme. The fraud can involve impairing, obstructing, or defeating the lawful functions of any government department through deceit or trickery. Contempt of Congress is punishable by statute or Congress's inherent powers, with the failure to obey a congressional subpoena being outlawed under 2 U.S.C. 192. The failure to obey a congressional subpoena or refusal to answer questioning at a congressional hearing is outlawed under 2 U.S.C. 192, punishable by imprisonment for up to one year and a fine of $100,000. Other federal statutes prohibit threats or violence to obstruct government activities, such as 18 U.S.C. 115 which prohibits violence against Members of Congress, judges, jurors, officials, and their families. Threats to commit offenses under this section can result in imprisonment for up to six years. Federal law protects federal officers, employees, and government witnesses from murder, manslaughter, attempted murder, and manslaughter during the performance of their duties. It also prohibits the murder, kidnapping, or assault of Members of Congress, Supreme Court Justices, or Cabinet Secretaries. Additionally, statutes outlaw assaults on federal officers responsible for enforcing specific federal laws and programs. Section 201 prohibits offering or soliciting bribes or illegal gratuities. Section 201 of federal law outlaws bribery in judicial, congressional, and administrative proceedings, with penalties including imprisonment, fines, and disqualification from federal positions. The mail fraud and wire fraud statutes cover obstruction of government activities through corruption schemes. Congress has expanded the scope of these statutes to prevent any deprivation of money, property, or honest services using mail or wire communications. The mail and wire fraud statutes were expanded by Congress with the passage of 18 U.S.C. 1346 to include a scheme to defraud element involving the deprivation of honest services. The Supreme Court clarified that this provision applies to bribery or kickback schemes using mail or wire communications. Prosecutors may opt for a fraud charge over bribery due to higher penalties, including up to 20 years in prison. Extortion under color of official right occurs when a public official receives an improper payment for an official act. Extortion under color of official right involves improper payments to public officials in exchange for official acts, leading to potential liability for public officers, employees, and their associates. The prosecution must show that the extortion affected interstate or foreign commerce, with violations punishable by up to 20 years in prison. Additionally, federal statutes such as 18 U.S.C. 1519 prohibit the destruction of evidence to obstruct justice. 18 U.S.C. 1519, 1520, and 2232(a) prohibit destruction of evidence, corporate audit records, and property to obstruct federal investigations. Other statutes like 18 U.S.C. 1503, 1512, 1621, 1622, and 1001 outlaw obstruction of justice through deception, perjury, and false statements to federal agencies. The obstruction of justice can lead to an enhancement of a sentence by up to four years, as per §3C1.1 of the United States Sentencing Guidelines. This enhancement applies if the defendant obstructed the administration of justice during the investigation, prosecution, or sentencing of the offense they were convicted of. The United States Sentencing Guidelines allow for a 2-level increase in the offense level if the defendant's obstructive conduct is related to the offense of conviction or a closely related offense. This enhancement can apply if the defendant committed perjury during trial or in other judicial contexts. The defendant in the case engaged in various forms of obstructive conduct, including perjury, false statements, and threats towards victims, witnesses, or jurors. The enhancement in the offense level can be applied when the defendant willfully testified falsely on a material matter or made false statements that could influence the issue at hand. The defendant engaged in obstructive conduct such as perjury, false statements, and threats towards victims, witnesses, or jurors, which can be considered obstruction of justice under criminal law.
